subject: Precise mechanism of the human eye
raw:
Photoreceptors. <[silence]> Optic nerve. <[silence]> Retinal layers. <[silence]> 

The human eye operates through a precise mechanism that begins with the entry of light through the cornea. <[silence]> This transparent, dome-shaped surface refracts light, directing it towards the pupil. <[silence]> The iris, a muscular structure, adjusts the pupil size to regulate the amount of light entering the eye. <[silence]> Behind the pupil lies the lens, which fine-tunes focus by changing shape, a process known as accommodation. <[silence]>

Once light passes through the lens, it reaches the retina, a multi-layered tissue at the back of the eye. <[silence]> The retina contains photoreceptors, specifically rods and cones, which convert light into electrical signals. <[silence]> Rods are responsible for vision in low light conditions, while cones detect color and detail in brighter settings. <[silence]> These signals are then transmitted to the brain via the optic nerve. <[silence]>

The optic nerve acts as a conduit, carrying visual information to the brain's visual cortex. <[silence]> Here, the brain processes and interprets these signals, allowing us to perceive images. <[silence]> This entire process occurs almost instantaneously, enabling seamless visual perception. <[silence]> Each component of the eye works in concert to ensure accurate image formation. <[silence]>

Three related subjects are the visual processing in the brain, the role of photoreceptors in color vision, and the impact of refractive errors on sight.
